title: Intentional anti-meta/bad pick should be punishable in Ranked if you are handicapping your team
body: I think many of you experienced how it feels to be forced to play around a bad pick, such as Pyke jungle, which clearly won't work. Overwatch started to weed out players, who intentionally hindered their team with bad picks, LoL should it too.

There are two fundamental components to this issue. First, why is the player choosing that champion? Second, what does their team think of it?

If the player knows it's bad and is doing it _because_ it's bad, so that they can increase their chances of losing in a way that's harder to detect than straight up inting (which often goes unpunished anyway; I dunno why people try to hide it, but anyway), that is considered griefing and is punishable with a 14-day suspension. I sometimes see the argument that a punished player was trying to win because they bought appropriate items, warded, called MIAs, etc., but they forget that they already stopped trying to win when they picked roaming Teemo support because making teammates rage with an unviable strategy is hilarious. When a player is "trying to win" except for all the things they did to try to lose, that's not actually trying to win. And they're not punished for the things they did right. They're punished for the things they did wrong.

If the player's teammates are firmly against trying an off-meta strategy and make it clear that they're not happy it, ignoring the team's request and doing whatever one wants is considered griefing and is punishable with a 14-day suspension.

_If_ the player is acting in good faith and making that pick to _win_ with an unexpected but viable strategy, _and_ their teammates are okay with it, then everything is fine.

> If the player's teammates are firmly against trying an off-meta strategy and make it clear that they're not happy it, ignoring the team's request and doing whatever one wants is considered griefing and is punishable with a 14-day suspension.

In the confine of this particular thread, picking off-meta (whatever this means) champion despite the entire team firmly against and making it clear they are not happy with it is NOT considered griefing or punishable by anything.  NOT playing in the position assigned (support leaving bot entire game, forced duo-jungle, etc.) is an entirely different topic of discussion that is not part of the thread.

That's pretty funny. It's not "bad" and they won't "punish" people for it, but they will lock the account and tell the player to stop it, only unlocking the account when the player agrees to change their behavior. And if they keep being disruptive, they get an actual punishment.

So, like I said, if someone knows that the team isn't okay with it and just does whatever they want because they couldn't care less about the people they got matched with and Riot doesn't punish off-meta picks, they actually will get punished. If they're somehow unaware of the trouble they're causing (only a few cases a year), they get this "not a punishment" lock and lecture.

I'd say that what I said is still accurate, but lacking mention of this extra procedure for the tiny category of clueless meta-breakers. Most people who appear to be troll picking probably are, so the advice of listening to the team remains valid.

Not sure where you got that from, to be honest. All it says is that the person will get feedback.

> And if they keep being disruptive, they get an actual punishment.

**Definitely** not sure where you got that from, since the post I linked specifically says that they will only reach out again if they find any "actual" behaviour problems, specifically citing unsportsmanlike conduct and outright trolling as requirements for a penalty, and even more specifically ruling out penalizing them for continuing to use weird picks with the intention of winning.

> [{quoted}](name=TrulyBland,realm=EUNE,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=fz8qVzEN,comment-id=000a00000000000100000000,timestamp=2020-01-23T06:52:46.927+0000)

Do you think the non-communicative player will be like "nah I'm gonna keep doing what I want" and the Rioter will be like "okay, we'll unlock your account and not bother you again"? The point of the talking-to is to teach the player the right way to behave and set up that expectation moving forward.

This is an "actual" behavior problem. If it wasn't, Riot would comb through thousands of reports to find a few players who need a special procedure of locking their account and getting a lecture from Riot on how to behave. It's special-cased because they don't want such players to be pushed onto the road to a permaban. But if the behavior doesn't improve, I don't see why the lock and lecture wouldn't repeat. The whole point is to change the player's problematic behavior, which isn't "weird picks" but rather "pissing off thousands of people," as "don't be a jerk" is of course the basic tenet of the ToS, Summoner's Code, etc.

I don't want people thinking that pissing off your team is okay if A or B or C, because it isn't. Even the gentlest "this isn't a punishment, we're just worried about you, son" is a sign that the behavior wasn't acceptable. We shouldn't be telling people they can play however they want. We should be telling them to communicate and be respectful.

> I don't want people thinking that pissing off your team is okay if A or B or C, because it isn't. Even the gentlest "this isn't a punishment, we're just worried about you, son" is a sign that the behavior wasn't acceptable. We shouldn't be telling people they can play however they want. We should be telling them to communicate and be respectful.

We shouldn't also make up rules just to scare people into not doing it.  People ARE allowed to play whatever they want and however they want within reasons (taking cs as support, taking jungle camp after the initial phase, taxing lane cs as jungler, picking Singed into any role with zero communication, etc.).

People ARE allowed to play whatever they want and however they want within reasons (taking cs as support, taking jungle camp after the initial phase, taxing lane cs as jungler, picking Singed into any role with zero communication, etc.).

I'm not making up any rules. People ask "can I play any way I want all the time" and the basic, stripped-down answer is "no, you have to at least communicate with your team." Since only a few players per year actually get this lock and lecture, and yet the question of whether players have to work with their team about off-meta choices comes up all the time, I'd say that the very vast majority of cases fall into one of two categories: acceptable play or griefing. I think it's important to caution that while the former is achievable through communication and teamwork, the latter is still very much punishable. It's all too common for people to troll with unviable picks but otherwise normal play and then attempt to wriggle out of a punishment with "I'm just playing to win differently." I'm not sure how this analogy will pan out, but I love analogies, so think of it like drinking during Prohibition. Alcohol was permitted for religious use, but I bet there were more than a few people who thought they could call a bottle of moonshine "sacramental" and get away with it.

> I'd say that the very vast majority of cases fall into one of two categories: acceptable play or griefing. I think it's important to caution that while the former is achievable through communication and teamwork, the latter is still very much punishable.

I agree that it it's important to caution people that griefing is punishable. I disagree heavily with the scaremonger tactics you are employing to achieve this. Whether something is acceptable play or griefing is not defined by your team's consent.

Using your analogy:
I acknowledge that you may be trying to make people aware of the laws of prohibition, even including the exceptions **and** including that you can't just pretend to be among the exceptions and expect to be spared.
The problem is that rather than sticking to the actual laws (as ambiguous as they may be) you are trying to pass off your **own** definition of "religious use" as the actual rule, which makes the prohibition seem much stricter than it actually is.

As a result you are no longer actually raising awareness of the law, as much as you are scaremongering people into the behaviour that **you** think should be considered acceptable.

>Do you think the non-communicative player will be like "nah I'm gonna keep doing what I want" and the Rioter will be like "okay, we'll unlock your account and not bother you again"? The point of the talking-to is to teach the player the right way to behave and set up that expectation moving forward.

Nowhere in the post does it say anything about a comment being required to begin with. It's about making sure that the player is aware of the way they affect other players and explaining to them how to mitigate that problem.

>This is an "actual" behavior problem.

"Actual" as a word highlights a contrast. If everything in that post was about an actual problem, then where is the contrast? Why would they use that word?

>If it wasn't, Riot would comb through thousands of reports to find a few players who need a special procedure of locking their account and getting a lecture from Riot on how to behave.

They're combing through reports as is. You're acting as if they are specifically trying to find these players, when they're really just doing manual reviews, especially if people have an unusual amount of reports. They're not actively trying to find these players, they're trying to find trolls and other players that slip through the cracks of the system.

>It's special-cased because they don't want such players to be pushed onto the road to a permaban. 

That doesn't explain the specific policy, since those players are only caught by manual reviews and, as a result, manual punishments. I know from certain cases from the forums that manual punishment also allows manually setting the next escalation step. They could easily stick to issuing 14 day bans, but they deliberately chose not to do that.

>But if the behavior doesn't improve, I don't see why the lock and lecture wouldn't repeat. 

Because, again, the policy is about making player aware of the problem. Once they have been made aware I don't see a reason why it would have to repeat.

>The whole point is to change the player's problematic behavior, which isn't "weird picks" but rather "pissing off thousands of people," as "don't be a jerk" is of course the basic tenet of the ToS, Summoner's Code, etc.
>
>I don't want people thinking that pissing off your team is okay if A or B or C, because it isn't.

Being a jerk isn't just pissing off people. Being a jerk is pissing off people **intentionally**. And this is the part that you consistently watering down.

Do you want to know how I once managed to piss off my team? By using spell vamp on a champion that dealt physical damage with their spells. People were convinced that spell vamp didn't work for physical damage spells.

Following your logic I was in the wrong there, despite the fact that the complaints my teammates had were **objectively invalid**.

> Snippet from a relevant Red post about a player who got punished for griefing after repeatedly picking support Singed even when his teammates weren't okay with it:

I would highlight the "if you are handicapping your team". And there is a difference between anti-meta and off-meta. Off-meta pick is technically any champion, which are sub-optimal on that role, but with skill it can work. Anti-meta pick is technically the same except it is so fundamentally flawed that with any minor game knowledge you know it is not going to work and would put the team into an inherent disadvantage. 

Why is Pyke and e.g Soraka an awful jungle pick and is considered trolling, whereas Aatrox is just off-meta? Simple answer:
- Aatrox can take objectives and have decentish clear, whereas Pyke and Soraka are going to struggle at the basic creeps as well.

Even when Pyke jungle was a thing, it was really really off-meta, but it was technically eliminated a year and half ago. Why would even one consider it still a legit pick in Ranked Solo Q? The Pyke jgl I had was struggling at the Krugs while the enemy Amumu had already twice as much farm, and when Pyke could finally commit himself to ganking, all lanes were lost, because Amumu kept ganking all of them. So his stupid pick cost 4 others the game. Is it okay? I don't care what a professional team did, because Solo Q Ranked =/= pro-scene

You also amuse me that you defend such players, yet you same people come here to tell Riot that their matchmaking is bad, because you got such players in some matches. You get such players, because you don't want stricter rules. Also Ranked is played, because players would prefer more serious matches, not to play with players, who want to try out idiotic, fundamentally broken picks. That's what Normal is for or play Ranked Flex with 4 others in a premade, who is going to tolerate such. If you don't aim to win, then play Blind Pick, but personally I enjoy the more serious toned matches where the aim is to win. I don't like playing matches with people, who don't even try from the beginning.
if off meta becomes punishable then so too will meta. one cannot exist without the other.
